Translated by the great Tang dynasty Trepiá¹­aka master Xuanzang, under imperial decreeğŸ”½It refers to the real nature of all dharmas.ğŸ”½The imaginary nature refers to the imaginary nature of all dharmas.
The conventional nature refers to the conventional nature of all dharmas.

The cause of arising refers to the four conditions such as the causal condition.
The cause of accomplishment refers to the three means of valid cognition:
First, direct perception; second, inference; third, verbal testimony.
The cause of transformation refers to the conformity with dependent origination.
The cause of reversion refers to the reversal of dependent origination.

The object with characteristics refers to the five sense objects such as form that are cognized by the five sense consciousnesses such as the eye consciousness, because the cognition that arises from cognizing these only has the characteristic of nondiscrimination.
The object with discrimination refers to the objects cognized by the mental consciousness, because the cognition that arises from cognizing these objects has discrimination.
The object of counteraction refers to the object that, when taken as object, abandons defilements, because it is able to counteract them.
The object of abiding refers to the object that, when taken as object, gives rise to the abodes of the noble ones, gods, and Brahmas, because it is the abode of the noble ones.
The object of increase refers to the object that, when taken as object, can progress and advance, because it is the cause of superior increase.

The object of decrease refers to the object that, when taken as object, can enter the attainment of non-perception and the attainment of cessation, because it is the cause of decreasing the mind and mental factors.
The object of mastery refers to the object that, when taken as object, gives rise to the superior qualities such as the supernormal powers, because it is the cause of mastery.
The mode of activity of analysis refers to the analysis of various categories of dharmas, such as form and non-form, visible and invisible, and so on.

The mode of activity of distinction refers to the meaning of the distinctions among dharmas, such as the single characteristic of faith, which is sometimes called mental purity, sometimes called delight, sometimes called acceptance, and so on.

The aspect of correct understanding refers to correctly understanding the characteristics of the objects of cognition through various aspects, such as the aspect of discrimination being called consciousness, the aspect of grasping images being called conceptualization, and the aspect of sensation being called feeling, and so forth.

The aspect of contemplation refers to the sixteen aspects, namely the four aspects of impermanence, etc., the four aspects of causes, etc., the four aspects of cessation, etc., and the four aspects of the path, etc.
Or the six worldly aspects, namely the aspect of coarseness, the aspect of obstruction, the aspect of suffering, the aspect of tranquility, the aspect of excellence, and the aspect of separation.

The aspect of action and subsequent action refers to acting and then subsequently acting again, such as having already well guarded through this action, then again giving rise to other subsequent guarding actions.

The same type of immediate condition refers to greed immediately giving rise to more greed, and the same is so for hatred, etc., because each different type immediately gives rise to more of the same.

As for the same kind of dharmas arising in succession, this means that when a dharma has just ceased, the dharma that is able to produce it immediately arises.

The dominant condition that is separated and uninterrupted refers to the mind and mental factors that arise before and after when one arises from the concentration of cessation, etc., because they are separated by an interval.
The dominant condition that is arising and uninterrupted refers to when a dharma arises in succession without interval after another dharma.

The dominant condition that is ceasing and uninterrupted refers to when a dharma ceases in succession without interval after another dharma, such as when the mind and mental factors cease without interval and then either enter the concentration of cessation, or enter the concentration of non-perception, or enter the realm of nirvÄá¹‡a without remainder.
The dominant condition that is grasping refers to the eyes, etc., which have a dominant power with regard to grasping objects.
The dominant condition that is birth refers to the male and female faculties, which have a dominant power with regard to the birth of embryos.
The dominant condition that is abiding refers to the life faculty, which has a dominant power with regard to the abiding of the body, etc.
The dominant condition that is the enjoyment of defilement refers to the five faculties of sensation, which have a dominant power with regard to what is enjoyed.
Also, because they are followed by craving, etc., that is, by the craving for pleasure, by hatred for suffering, and by delusion regarding neither pleasure nor suffering.

The dominant influence of purity refers to the five faculties of faith, etc., and the three faculties of knowing what has not been known, etc., because they have the power to dominate in the matter of the purity that is mundane and supramundane.
The dominant influence of the field refers to the common karma, because it has the power to dominate in the production of the receptacle world.
The dominant influence of support refers to the four great elements, because they have the power to dominate in supporting derivative form.
The support of the realms refers to the body that is included in the desire realm, etc.
The support of the destinies refers to the body that is included in the five destinies.
The support of the continents refers to JambudvÄ«pa, etc.ğŸ”½The support of villages and fields refers to that by which villages and fields exist, and it is that by which they are supported.
The support of the person refers to that by which the person exists, and it is that by which he is supported.
The basis of non-sickness means that if something exists based on non-sickness, it uses that as its basis.
The basis of precepts means that if something exists based on precepts, it uses that as its basis.
The basis of adornment means that if something arises based on the various adornments and merits of a Å›ramaá¹‡a, it uses that as its basis.
The basis of requisites means the four bases, namely robes and so forth.
The basis of good friends means that if something arises based on this good and so forth, it uses that as its basis.
The basis of the Dharma means the twelve divisions of the teachings such as sÅ«tras and so forth.
The basis of attention means the seven kinds of attention, namely the attention of understanding characteristics and so forth.
The basis of samÄdhi means the seven bases of concentration.
As a sÅ«tra says:
I say that based on the first dhyÄna one can exhaust all defilements, and so forth, up to based on the sphere of nothingness one can also do so.
As for the classification in terms of realms, it means the seeds of the various realms, because they can include the dharmas produced by the seeds.
As for mutual inclusion, it means that the intrinsic characteristics of dharmas can still include themselves.
As for inclusion by type, it means that according to the types of form, there are ten sense bases and the form aggregate included, and so forth.
As for inclusion by state, it means that what is included is in the state of being conducive to the experience of pleasure, etc.
As for inclusion by associates, it means that form is included in the five aggregates, because they are its retinue, and so forth.
As for inclusion by time, it means that the past, etc., include the past, etc.
As for inclusion by direction, it means that the aggregates, etc., that exist in this direction are included in this direction.
As for inclusion by complete parts, it means that the forms of the desire, form, and formless realms, and the pure forms, include all forms.
As for inclusion by partial parts, it means that the eye faculty includes the form aggregate, and so forth.
As for mutual inclusion, it means that the aggregates, sense bases, and elements mutually include each other.
As for inclusion by ultimate truth, it means that dharmas are included in impermanence, suffering, impurity, emptiness, and non-self, and in suchness.
The associated with other natures means that they are associated with other natures, not with their own nature.

The associated with non-contradiction means that although they are associated with other natures, they are not contradictory, but non-contradictory, like craving and hatred, pleasure and pain, and so on.

The associated with universal mental factors means that contact, feeling, perception, volition, and attention are associated with all minds, while the four afflictions of ignorance, conceit, craving for self, and the view of a real self are associated with defiled mind.
The associated with non-universal mental factors means that, excluding the universal mental factors, the remaining craving, etc., and faith, etc., are associated.
The associated with the objects to be eliminated means that the various afflictions are associated with each other.
The associated with the means of elimination means that the wholesome dharmas included in the path of elimination are associated with each other.
The associated with what has been practiced means that, excluding the supramundane dharmas and the dharmas attained after the supramundane, the remaining associated dharmas are associated.
The associated with what has not been practiced means that the associated dharmas excluded above are associated.
The inferior corresponding means the corresponding dharmas included in the ÅšrÄvaka and Pratyekabuddha vehicles.
The vast corresponding means the corresponding dharmas possessed by all Buddhas and Bodhisattvas.
The accomplishment of the seven kinds of purity, such as the defiled consciousness, etc., has already been explained, and will not be repeated.

The eight what words refer to what, who believes, what is believed, by what is believed, for what is believed, by what is believed, what of it is believed, in what is believed, and how much is believed.

The eight if words refer to if one is able to believe, if what is believed, if by what is believed, if for what is believed, if by what is believed, if that is believed, if in what is believed, and if that much is believed.
In this way, there are immeasurably many such approaches.ğŸ”½Not ultimately escaping means by means of the worldly path.
Ultimately escaping means by means of the supramundane path.
The first four are easy to understand, so they are not explained again.
The profound characteristics refer to the three natures.
The profound defilement refers to suchness, which is said to be defiled without being defiled.
The profound purity refers to suchness, which is said to be pure without being pure.
The profound dependent arising refers to the fact that there is no dharma that has real efficacy in the arising of other dharmas, yet those dharmas arise in various ways.
Moreover, there is no real self, yet a self appears.
The profound karma refers to the fact that there is karma and there are karmic results, but the agent cannot be found.
The profound wisdom refers to nondiscriminating cognition.
How can this cognition, which is without discrimination, clearly perceive the nature of suchness?
The profound birth refers to the fact that bodhisattvas, without the power of karma and afflictions, manifest birth.
The profound enlightenment refers to the fact that in the uncontaminated realm, the enlightenment of buddhas cannot be established as a single nature, because it is realized by innumerable continua.
It cannot be established as various natures, because the basis is without distinction.

The profound of the buddhas refers to the fact that in a great assembly there are immeasurable and boundless buddhas, world-honored ones, with various bodies and various intentions, yet they are not considered to have differences between self and others.
Moreover, the transformation bodies of buddhas do not abide in the characteristics of buddhas, yet they are able to create various buddha-works.
The profound of the teachings refers to the fact that in the teachings of the Mahayana there are various secret intentions and distinctions, the three gates of liberation and all dharmas.
Desire as the root, etc., have already been explained their characteristics and will not be repeated.
The skillful means of upholding refers to the skillful means related to the accumulations.

The skillful means of yoga refers to shamatha and vipashyana.ğŸ”½The skillful means of characteristics refers to the skillful means related to the characteristics of calming, uplifting, and equanimity.
The skillful means of discernment refers to the skillful means related to the factors conducive to discernment.
The distant expedient means refers to the expedient means of upholding.
The proximate expedient means refers to the expedient means of discernment.
The proximate and distant expedient means refers to the two kinds of expedient means of yoga and characteristics.
In the stage of heat, it is called proximate, and in the expedient means of upholding, it is called distant, because it is far from the holy path.
Penetration, cultivation, and perfect realization have already been explained elsewhere, so they are not repeated here.
The ultimate of cognition refers to the cognition of exhaustion and non-arising.
The ultimate of abandonment refers to the complete and permanent abandonment of all afflictions.ğŸ”½The ultimate of the absolute refers to that which is accomplished by the supramundane path.
The ultimate of the non-absolute refers to that which is accomplished by the mundane path.
The ultimate of the inferior refers to that of the Å›rÄvakas and pratyekabuddhas.
The ultimate of the vast refers to that of the buddhas and bodhisattvas.
The ultimate of the bodhisattvas refers to that in the final stage.
As for the Buddhas' ultimate, it means that when unobstructed cognition arises, it is like hundreds of thousands of koá¹­is of suns appearing simultaneously.
The twenty kinds of elicitation have already been extensively explained above.
As for the summary of ascertainment, it means that all ascertainment is included in ten topics.
What are the ten topics?

Namely, the ascertainment of what is to be done, the ascertainment of entry, the ascertainment of superior resolve, the ascertainment of principles, the ascertainment of treatises, the ascertainment of penetration, the ascertainment of purity, the ascertainment of elicitation, the ascertainment of the distinctions of phrases, and the ascertainment of the accomplishment of all meanings at the time of temporarily directing one's thoughts without effort.
As for the ascertainment of what is to be done, it means being able to ascertain the various worldly means of livelihood and so forth.
As for the ascertainment of entry, it means being able to contemplate which vehicle among the three vehicles one should enter,
and how to cause others to also enter.
As for the ascertainment of superior resolve, it means giving rise to superior faith and understanding according to the teachings one has heard through the wisdom of hearing.
Ascertainment of principles refers to the discernment of the meanings expressed in the scriptures through the wisdom of reflection.
Ascertainment of treatises refers to the establishment of treatises based on what one has heard and reflected upon, in order to cause others to enjoy the bliss of the Dharma.
Ascertainment of penetration refers to the path of seeing, because it can penetrate the truth.
Ascertainment of purification refers to the path of cultivation, because it can purify all afflictions without remainder.
Ascertainment of invocation refers to the path of added effort, because it can invoke superior merits.
Ascertainment of distinctions in phrases refers to the method of expounding the distinctions of limitless Dharma meanings through the distinctions of two, three, four, or more phrases.

Ascertainment of accomplishing all meanings effortlessly and spontaneously refers to the wisdom of the TathÄgata, because when he briefly directs his mind to all meanings without prior effort, his unobstructed wisdom and insight arises.
Ascertainment of the rules of treatises is of seven kinds:

First, the essence of debate; second, the place of debate; third, the basis of debate; fourth, the adornments of debate; fifth, the defeats in debate; sixth, the means of extricating oneself from defeat in debate; seventh, the rules for debate.
Being skilled in these seven topics is called the discernment of the rules of debate.
As for the essence of debate, there are six kinds:
First, verbal debate; second, esteemed debate; third, contentious debate; fourth, slanderous debate; fifth, conforming debate; sixth, instructive debate.
Verbal debate refers to all worldly speech.
Esteemed debate refers to debates that are followed by the world, because they are esteemed by worldly wisdom.ğŸ”½Contentious debate refers to debates in which opposing positions are put forward.
Slanderous debate refers to debates in which harsh words are exchanged out of mutual resentment.
Conforming debate refers to debates that discern in accordance with pure wisdom and insight.

Instructive debate refers to debates that teach and guide sentient beings, causing those whose minds are not yet settled to settle their minds and those whose minds are already settled to attain liberation.

As for the place of debate, it is either in the king's palace, or in the court, or in front of upright and reliable people, or in front of good companions, or in front of Å›ramaá¹‡as, brÄhmaá¹‡as, etc. who understand the meaning of the Dharma and the scriptures, and there one initiates the debate.
As for the king's palace, it refers to a place where the king himself is present.
As for the court, it refers to a place where the king's affairs are decided.
As for upright and reliable people, it refers to merchants and others.
As for good companions, it refers to those who establish arguments among companions, and the opponents do not go beyond their words.
As for Å›ramaá¹‡as, brÄhmaá¹‡as, etc. who understand the meaning of the Dharma and the scriptures, it refers to those who have thoroughly penetrated the texts and meanings in various treatises.
As for the basis of debate, it refers to what is relied upon to establish an argument. In brief, there are two kinds:
first, what is to be established; second, what is able to establish.
As for what is to be established, there are two kinds:
first, the intrinsic nature; second, the distinctions.

There are eight kinds of what can be established: 1. Proposing a thesis, 2. Stating a reason, 3. Stating an example, 4. Combining [reason and example], 5. Concluding, 6. Direct perception, 7. Inference, 8. Scriptural authority.
As for self-nature, it refers to the self-nature of the self and the self-nature of dharmas, whether existent or non-existent, that are to be established.

As for distinctions, they refer to the distinctions of the self and distinctions of dharmas, whether they are all-pervading or not all-pervading, whether they are permanent or impermanent, whether they have form or are formless, and so on, with innumerable distinctions.
Proposing a thesis means using one's own accepted meaning that should be established to proclaim it to others, causing them to understand it.
Why is this so?ğŸ”½If one does not say what should be established, then establishing one's own position and proclaiming it to others should be called proposing a thesis.
If one does not say one's own accepted meaning, then proclaiming the meaning that should be established in another's position should be called proposing a thesis.
If one does not say to others, then merely stating this would be considered the establishment of a thesis.
If one does not say to make others understand, then using one's body to indicate this meaning would be considered the establishment of a thesis.
If one does not say to make others understand clearly, then if the listener does not yet understand this meaning, it would be considered the establishment of a thesis.

If it is free from all faults to the extent that it is established, then establishing the nature of self and dharmas as existent or non-existent, the pervasiveness or non-pervasiveness of the distinctions of self and dharmas, and so forth, with all the preceding characteristics, is called the establishment of a thesis.

The establishment of reasons refers to correctly stating the characteristics of what is to be believed and understood, such as whether or not something can be perceived by valid cognition, regarding a meaning that is not yet clear in what is being established.
The characteristics of what is to be believed and understood are the meaning of the reasons for belief and understanding.
Why is this?

Because by correctly proclaiming the characteristics of what can and cannot be perceived by valid cognition, and so forth, the understanding that arises from what is to be accomplished but is not yet clear gives rise to the belief and understanding that is to be attained. Therefore, correctly proclaiming those characteristics is called the establishment of reasons.
Obtained or not obtained by direct perception refers to the basis and the characteristics.
Simile means to properly explain by combining what has been seen with what has not been seen.
What has been seen refers to the already manifest part.
What has not been seen refers to the not yet manifest part.
The proper explanation that manifests the manifest and unmanifest parts, making the meaning equal, is called simile.
Application means to draw in the remaining meanings of this kind and properly explain the principle with regard to this dharma.

That is to say, having established the previously established meaning with the three parts, in order to further establish the remaining meanings of this kind that are to be established, one draws in those meanings and properly explains the principle with regard to this dharma. This is called application.
Conclusion means the proper explanation that reaches the ultimate point.
Because this principle is extremely well accomplished, therefore this matter is definitely without difference, and the conclusion is reached. This is called conclusion.
Having already explained the characteristics of establishing a thesis, etc., now we will briefly illustrate them in terms of a matter.
For example, a proponent of no-self, when discussing the self with a proponent of self, first states that all dharmas are without self.
This statement is establishing a thesis.
Next, he states, Because four errors can be found in positing a self in the aggregates.
This statement is establishing a reason.
Why is it so?
If a real self is posited in the aggregates, is this conceived self the same as the characteristics of the aggregates?
Or is it within the aggregates?
Or is it in some other place?
Or is it posited as not belonging to the aggregates?
If it is posited as the same as the characteristics of the aggregates, the aggregates are not independent, arising from many conditions, and are dharmas that arise and cease.
If they are the same as those characteristics, I am not established. This is called the first error.
If it is posited as being within the aggregates, the supported aggregates being impermanent, the supported self should also be impermanent. This is the second error.
If it is established elsewhere apart from the aggregates, then the self would have no cause and no function, which is the third fault.
If it is established without belonging to the aggregates, then the self would exist alone, liberated by its own nature, and further seeking liberation would be useless, which is the fourth fault.
Next, it is said that the past is established in the same way as the present.
This statement is a metaphor.
Why is it so?
If the past is established as truly existent with the same characteristics as the present, then the past that is conceived would be the same as the present characteristics.
Is it within the present?
Is it elsewhere?
Or is it established without depending on the present?

If it is established with the same characteristics as the present, then that which has arisen but not yet ceased is the characteristic of the present. The essence of the past dharma should also have the characteristic of having arisen but not yet ceased, which is the first fault.
If it is established in the present, it is established in the unceased, and it is not reasonable for the essence of cessation to be unrelated, so this is the second fault.
If it is established elsewhere apart from the present, apart from the present, no part of the real conditioned thing can be obtained, so how can it be established in that?
This is the third fault.
If it is established without depending on the present, it should also be established that the unconditioned is the past, which is the fourth fault.
However, because the characteristics of the past are destroyed, the meaning of characteristics is established.
If it is established in the same way as the present, it immediately becomes four faults, so the characteristics of the past are not established.
The selflessness of all dharmas is also like this. If it is established in the aggregates, then the four faults can be obtained, so the meaning of selflessness is established.
Next, it is said that after thus refuting the error of self, by this principle permanence, etc. also do not exist.
This statement is a combination.
Later it is said that by this principle, therefore the five aggregates are all impermanent, up to being without self.
This statement is the conclusion.
Direct perception means that which is self-evident, clear, and free from confusion.
The phrase self-evident indicates that it is self-evidently grasped, like the eyes correctly grasping form and so forth.

This phrase is to distinguish from the worldly commonly accepted things that are directly perceived, such as pots, which are accepted as being directly perceived, because they are imputed and therefore not directly perceived.
The word clear is to distinguish from objects that are not directly perceived due to obscurations and other such causes.
The phrase free from confusion is to distinguish from things like a whirling fire wheel or a mirage.
Inference means that which is directly perceived and believed.
What is this?
It means that, excluding that which is directly perceived, the rest are not directly perceived but are ascertained to occur together.
Having previously seen something complete, when now a part of it is directly perceived, correct belief arises regarding the remaining parts.
It means that they will definitely exist here, because they occur together.
Like seeing smoke in the distance and knowing there is fire, this is called inference preceded by direct perception.
The authority of the scriptures means the teachings that do not contradict the two authorities.
What is this?
It means that all teachings that are not contradicted by direct perception or inference are definitely reliable and trustworthy, and are therefore called the authority of the scriptures.

As for the adornments of the treatise, it means that based on the correct principles of the treatise, one initiates discussions that are profoundly good and beautiful, which are called the adornments of the treatise.
This is further of six kinds:
1. Being well-versed in one's own and others' schools, 2. Having a perfect voice, 3. Fearlessness, 4. Eloquence, 5. Dignity, and 6. Being worthy of offerings.
Being well-versed in one's own and others' schools means being thoroughly familiar with and clearly understanding the texts and meanings of one's own and others' schools, without interruption.

Complete in sound means that one first initiates a discussion only after skillfully understanding the theories of sound, free from the faults of the spoken words to be uttered, and the spoken words that are emitted are free from confusion and so forth.
Fearless means that even when surrounded by an immeasurable number of exceptionally intelligent and obstinate opponents in a great assembly, the spoken words are fearless.
Eloquence means that the words are free from obstruction.
Respectful means that the words are not abrupt, and one observes the words of the debating opponent to the end before speaking.
Worthy of offerings means that one's nature is upright and harmonious, one's speech is gentle and kind, and one skillfully accords with the minds of the debating opponents.
Defeat in debate means abandoning speech, verbal defeat, and verbal faults.
Due to these three, debaters fall into a state of defeat and accept the defeat of others.
Abandoning speech means oneself speaking of one's own debate faults and speaking of the virtues of the other's debate, saying I am not good and You are good and so forth.

As for retraction, it means to retreat by resorting to other matters as a pretext, or to abandon one's original position by speaking of external matters, or to show anger, arrogance, and concealment, as explained in detail in the sutras.
As for retreating by resorting to other matters as a pretext, it means to confuse what is being discussed by resorting to other matters.
As the sutras say:
The elder Chandrakirti debated with non-Buddhists, either criticizing his own established position or establishing a position and then criticizing it.
As for faults, there are nine kinds in brief:
1. Confusion, 2. Harshness, 3. Unclearness, 4. Unlimitedness, 5. Dissonance, 6. Inappropriateness, 7. Indecision, 8. Unclarity, 9. Discontinuity.
Confusion means abandoning the discussed matter and speaking extensively about something else.
Harshness means being angry and abrupt, with words that are hasty and impetuous.
Unclearness means the Dharma and meaning being spoken are not understood by the assembly or the opponent.
Unlimited means the words are repeated, and the meaning may be increased or decreased.
Not corresponding to the meaning has five types:

1. Meaningless, 2. Contradictory to the meaning, 3. Harming the principle, 4. Equal to what is to be established, 5. Meaning that attracts faults and difficulties, because it cannot be obtained, because the meaning is not appropriate, because it is uncertain, because the established principle needs to be established again, and because all discussions are followed by what is unreasonable and untrue.
Inappropriate time means what should be said is not in the proper sequence.
Uncertain means establishing and then criticizing, criticizing and then establishing again, quickly changing and difficult to understand.
Unclear means going beyond the characteristics of the treatise and answering without understanding, or the words are mixed up between classical and vernacular.
Not continuous means the words are interrupted in the middle.

As for the topic of disengagement, it means observing the merits and demerits to make the discussion disengage, or else not engaging in discussion for fear of falling into a losing position. Even if one does engage in discussion, one is able to skillfully reach the end.
Moreover, if one knows that the opponent is not a suitable vessel for the Dharma, that the assembly lacks virtue, and that one lacks skill, one should not engage in discussion.
If one knows that the opponent is a suitable vessel for the Dharma, that the assembly has virtue, and that one has skill, then one may engage in discussion.
As for the opponent not being a suitable vessel for the Dharma, it means that they are unable to leave behind unwholesomeness and establish wholesomeness.
As for the assembly lacking virtue, it means being impure, delighting in biased attachment, having partiality, and so forth.
As for oneself lacking skill, it means not being well-versed in the body of the discussion up to the adornments of the discussion.
The opposite of this is called the opponent being a suitable vessel for the Dharma and so forth.
As for the topic of what is to be done in many ways, it means there are roughly three kinds of necessary principles for initiating a discussion.
What are the three?
First, one thoroughly understands one's own and others' tenets, thereby being able to engage in discussions everywhere, because one engages in discussions about all verbal matters.
Second, one is fearless, thereby being able to engage in discussions in the presence of all assemblies.
Third, one has eloquence, thereby being able to skillfully answer all questions and challenges.
Moreover, if one wishes to seek one's own benefit and happiness, one should thoroughly understand the rules of debate and should not engage in disputes with others.
As the Blessed One said in the MahÄyÄna Abhidharma SÅ«tra:

If bodhisattvas wish to diligently cultivate wholesome practices, wish to practice the true Dharma and follow the Dharma, wish to benefit all beings, and wish to quickly attain supreme perfect enlightenment, they should contemplate the twelve bases of cognition and should not engage in disputes with others.
What are the twelve?
First, when expounding the subtle Dharma of realizing the unsurpassed meaning, it is very difficult to find those who have faith and understanding.
Second, it is very difficult to find those who listen with a receptive mind and ask questions.
Third, it is very difficult to find an assembly of virtuous people who observe virtues and faults.
Fourth, it is very difficult to find those who engage in discussions while avoiding the six faults.
What are the six?

They are the fault of clinging to wrong views, the fault of speaking in a confused manner, the fault of speaking inappropriately, the fault of verbal defeat, the fault of harsh speech, and the fault of mental anger.
Fifth, it is very difficult to find those who engage in discussions without harboring malice.
Sixth, it is very difficult to find those who engage in discussions while skillfully guarding the minds of others.
Seventh, it is very difficult to find those who engage in discussions while skillfully guarding their own minds.
Eighth, it is very difficult to find those who engage in discussions with the intention of making themselves inferior and others superior.
Ninth, it is very difficult to find those whose minds are not disturbed when they are inferior and others are superior.
Tenth, it is extremely difficult for a mind that has already been afflicted to attain peace and stability.
